info: [ˈiːtɪŋ hæbɪts] – e.g. I developed poor eating habits at university and ate only fast food.
[hʌnt] – e.g. She spent a year hunting for a better job.
[ˈhʌntə] – sb who hunts wild animals for food or sport
[bɜːθ] – <> death
[ˈfɑːmɪŋ] – growing crops and raising animals
[pəˈsjuː] – to try to get sb/sth
[ˈfuːd səplaɪ] – phr food supply chain
[ˌhʌnt ˈdaʊn] – to find sb who doesn't want to be found
[tempt] – n temptation
[ˌtræk ˈdaʊn] – e.g. I tracked down old school friends with the help of social media.
[ˌsniːk ˈɪn] – pp sneaked/snuck
[ˌfriː ˈsɑːmpl] – e.g. The supermarket offered free samples of the products on sale.
[trɪk] – n trick, trickery
[ˌhaɪ ɪn ˈʃʊɡə] – <> low in sugar
[ˈdelɪkət] – e.g. Money is always a delicate subject.
[dʒʌdʒ] – to form an opinion about sb/sth, often negative
[feɪl] – <> to succeed; to no longer function

en: to be the stuff of sth
de: der Gegenstand von etw sein; der Stoff sein, aus dem etw ist
info: [bi ðə ˈstʌf əv] – e.g. Her adventures are the stuff of legend.
[ˈtʃaɪldhʊd meməriz] – e.g. My earliest childhood memories are of the park we always visited.
[ˈdaɪət] – what you eat
[kɔːz əv ˈdeθ] – e.g. The body was examined to determine the cause of death.

en: to be allowed to do sth
info: [bi əˈlaʊd tə du:] – e.g. In life, you're not always allowed to do the things you want to do.
[ˌfeləʊ ˈiːtə] – other guests at a restaurant
[ˌʌnˈwel] – e.g. Why didn't you tell us you were feeling unwell?
